data.title: The .gitignore file logo is GitHub's logo
data.body: `.gitignore` files are [a convention of Git](https://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore). GitHub is a git hosting service and private corporation, among many others, that use this convention. vscode should be using one of the [git logos](https://git-scm.com/downloads/logos) for .gitignore and other git-related file types.

data.title: Disable "Unable to open file" during debug
File explorer is not updated

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hello,

I noticed that sometimes (often ?) the file explorer doesn't get updated (missing files/folder) after creating new files/folders with something like a git pull or using symfony console to generate files.

Refreshing the explorer using the little refresh icon make the files/folders appear.

This is a follow up of this issue https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24309

- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Fedora 25

Thanks !

data.title: Improve usability on portrait monitors
data.body:
I prefer to use a monitor in portrait mode for editing code. (Or one portrait and one landscape.)
Currently there are some issues when using this configuration:
- The sidebar has a minimum width is not changeable and should be able to change the font size seperatly
- The sidebar is used for search results - there should be an option to put search results on the bottom panel with the other tabs (Problems, Output, etc.)
- No tear-off editors movable to other monitors

data.title: fontLigatures stopped working (Fira Code)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 
```
Version 1.13.0
Commit 376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf
Date 2017-06-08T16:41:25.571Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
```
- OS Version:
```
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 17.04
Release:	17.04
Codename:	zesty
```
Steps to Reproduce:
*I don't know if this is necessarily steps to reproduce, because I'm having a hard time finding anyone else with this problem*
1. Install Visual Studio Code
2. Install Fira Code fonts from the link on github
3. Set the settings in Visual Studio Code:
``` json
{
    "editor.fontFamily": "Fira Code",
    "editor.fontSize": 14,
    "editor.fontLigatures": true
}
```
or
``` json
{
    "editor.fontFamily": "'Fira Code'",
    "editor.fontSize": 14,
    "editor.fontLigatures": true
}
```
4. Install System76 Pop theme
5. Use Tweak tool to set suggested fonts (some are Fira Code)
6. Start missing out on Ligature awesomeness.

For reference, here is my complete VS Code settings file currently:
``` json
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite the default settings
{
    "editor.fontFamily": "Fira Code",
    "editor.fontSize": 14,
    "editor.fontLigatures": true,
    "files.autoSave": "afterDelay",
    "window.zoomLevel": 0,
    "files.autoSaveDelay": 3000,
    "workbench.iconTheme": "vs-seti",
    "files.exclude": {
        "**/*.js": {
            "when": "$(basename).ts"
        },
        "**/*.map": {
            "when": "$(basename).map"
        }
    },
    "typescript.tsdk": "./node_modules/typescript/lib",
    "editor.formatOnSave": true,
    "html.format.wrapLineLength": 60,
    "html.format.wrapAttributes": "auto",
    "html.format.unformatted": "",
    "typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled": true
}
```
Here are the GitHub issues I've already tried to open with other parties involved to try and learn what is going on.  I would love to troubleshoot this myself, I just don't know how:
https://github.com/system76/pop-gtk-theme/issues/30
https://github.com/tonsky/FiraCode/issues/435#issuecomment-307352385

data.title: window.openFilesInNewWindow: 'default' update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64 pro

With `window.openFilesInNewWindow` now defaulting to `off` ; I would really like to see the behavior of the `default` option be retooled;   
From the current: _files will open in the window with the files' folder open or the last active window unless opened via the dock or from finder (macOS only)_   

To: _If file is present in a folder which is open in an existing editor, open therein. Else file(s) will be opened in a new editor_

Primary change being the removal of _most recent editor_

Specifically this becomes annoying for me when opening files from the context menu in Windows explorer.

data.title: Incorrect word wrapping with Unicode quotes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

When word wrapping is enabled, the editor should only break lines at space characters.  (More precisely, I suppose it should break lines at any of the Unicode space characters which are not specifically designated as non-breaking.)  Unfortunately at the moment it also breaks lines between alphabetic characters and adjacent Unicode quotes.  For example, it will not break **don't** because it only contains an ASCII quote.  However, it will break **don’t** because it contains U+2019, the right single quotation mark.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Turn on word wrap in a buffer, with the "editor.wordWrap" configuration option.
2. Enter a word with a Unicode quote, for example by copying **don’t** from the paragraph above.
3. Enter more text to the left of the word **don’t** until it wraps.
4. Observe that it first wraps by moving the **t** onto the next line, leaving the rest of the word behind.

data.title: NPM module autocomplete (Mocha) turns on only after creating a jsconfig.json file
data.body:
Hey,

I've noticed some odd behavior whilst using **mocha** inside a React app. In fact, I've noticed this on other modules, too, but I'm providing the **mocha** example here.

Initially, some modules (mocha) do not provide any intellisense. It is only after creating an empty jsconfig.json file that intellisense is turned on. The opposite is also true - after deleting the empty jsconfig.json file, intellisense (for some modules, like **mocha**) is turned off.

I wonder if there is a bug lurking in VS Code responsible for this?

![](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUA7bfDDGF8ihd9LdS/giphy.gif)

- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows_NT

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a not support file type but still a text file (e.g. `a.xyz`)
2. Save as a `b.xyz` by enter **b** in the save file field. (File type show as Plain Text)
3. If the destination does not have a .txt file, it will save as `b.xyz`. But if the destination have a .txt file, it will save as `b.txt`

data.title: Hijack of Show In File Manger on Debian and PyCharm
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: debian 8.8 (x64-86) Linux kernel 3.16.0-4-amd64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. PyCharm (5) is installed before VSCode
2. Install VS Code
3. Install Python Module
4.  right click folder in PyCharm for any previously created project
5. Click "Show in File Manager"
6. VS Code now opens instead of the default Linux file manager. (unwanted)

Note: Before install of VS Code "Show In File Manger" correctly opens the OS File manager as expected.

To be clear, I am not raising  this issue because of PyCharm. I'm raising this issue because VSCode should not hijack the default "Show In File Manager" from other development tools.

Extensions Installed are:
C# for Visual Studio Code (Powered by OmniSharp)
Python 0.6.4 (Don Jayamanne)

data.title: Feature request: vscode.CompletionItem::documentation should support markdown
data.body:
This has bugged me since a while, and I just saw the new [Suggestion list and documentation side by side](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_13#_suggestion-list-and-documentation-side-by-side) feature in the 1.13.0 release notes and was hoping this would also finally enable markdown, but unfortunately that's not the case. It's even visible in the demo gif in the release notes where links are not formatted.

I'm [writing an autocomplete extension](https://github.com/simonvizzini/vscode-factorio-lua-api-autocomplete) and have this problem:

This looks nice and is helpful ``vscode.Hover``:

![nice-tooltip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10862380/27003351-1b2e0904-4df5-11e7-9a96-6578ca24e5a0.png)

But this not so much ``vscode.CompletionItem``:

![ugly-tooltip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10862380/27003353-2bcd5576-4df5-11e7-931b-08df12e0dd88.png)

Prior to 1.13.0 there was also no horizontal scrollbar and the lack of space doesn't make it easy to read.

Please consider also enabling markdown for CompletionItems. That would be really helpful. Thanks!

- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063 --- While working on a custom tree view for the Haxe extension, I noticed that the explorer sometimes crashed (not displaying any content until VSCode is reloaded). This seems to happen whenever an extension with a tree view is activated while the explorer hasn't been shown yet. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Check out and build the [tree-view-sample](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/master/tree-view-sample) extension. 2. Add `*` to the `package.json`'s `activationEvents`. 3. data.title: MenuKey remapped by AutoHotKey can not work well

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64 v1703 build 10.0.15063

# Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use `AutoHotKey` v1.1.24.5 to map Right Alt Key `RAlt` to the MenuKey:
``` ahk
RAlt:: Send {Appskey}
```

2. This hotkey works well on Windows Explorer, Notepad, Microsoft Word, Chrome, Notepad++. Software's context menu is showing when Right Alt key is released (keyup).

3.  This hotkey **usually fails to work** on VSCode:
- 1. VSCode shows its context menu (which seems to be correct)
- 2. press 'ArrowDown' to select the `Shift+F12` (search all references), and then press Enter
- 3. then VSCode **shows the same context menu again**, which is not expected
      (although sometimes it shows reference view correctlly)
- 4. repeat action 2
- 5. **sometimes VSCode shows a "plain" context menu** only including cut/copy/paste/delete, or it just hides the second context menu
- 6. if step 5 shows a plain menu, then `Esc` will close it.
- during step 4, if you press `Esc` instead, VSCode may hide the menu and show what I want.

4. This problem seems to happen depending what action runs firstly, and if you fail to reproduce it, please close VSCode completely and re-run it for several times, or you may repeat step 1-3 again and again. I'm sure this is a bug and I've met it for days.

# What's in Developer Tools:

VSCode and Chrome both gets such events: `keyup.Alt`, `keydown.ContextMenu`, `keyup.ContextMenu`, but **VSCode shows context menu at once on `keydown.ContextMenu`**. In my tests, many common softwares including Notepad, Explorer, Word, will show a context menu only on a `keyup` event.

I've tested the newest `Electron` demo application (Win x64, downloaded from https://electron.atom.io/), and it also responds only to `keyup`. So I think VSCode should change this behavior to keep the same as others.

data.title: OSX shell directory is appearing twice in Integrated Terminal

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS X Version: 10.11.2

Current working directory is appearing twice in after upgrading to 1.13.0. I have deleted all user and workspace settings, but the problem still persists.
![ezgif-3-7c73bce357](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6998650/27001915-281d9f4e-4e18-11e7-8b63-eaeaa672d0f1.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install / Upgrade Visual Code version 1.13.0 on OSX 10.11.2.
2. `View` -> `Integrated Terminal`

### Workaround
Interestingly, [fish](https://fishshell.com) shell is not experiencing this problem. I have switched temporarily to fish 
```$ brew install fish```

data.title: Show Suggestions and Hints in a fixed location instead of in a pop-up near the cursor
data.body:
This is a feature request for a new user interface component which is responsible for showing and interacting with Suggestions and Hints.

Currently, a user has two options for interacting with Suggestions and Hints: have them pop-up automatically as they type, or to trigger them manually with a keystroke (excepting a [bug](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28393) for Hints).

There are problems with both approaches, and I believe there could be a happy compromise between the two. First, the simple problem with *manual* triggering is that it takes extra effort to get the information that a programmer wants. Ask anyone who relies a lot on auto-suggestions or hints and they will tell you how useful it can be to *always* have this information on their screen, with no extra effort on their part.

However, there are problems with the auto-suggestions:

* At the most basic level, they can be visually distracting with constant movement in a variable part of the screen
* They can cover up other code that you'd like to be able to see while you're typing
* They also often take control of various keyboard inputs, though in most cases this can be disabled.

I think it would be great to have a panel (say, taking up a portion of the left sidebar, at the bottom, underneath the Explorer/Search/SCM/etc content), which stays in a fixed position on the screen and displays this context-aware information, without covering up any of the Editor.

This feature request is filed due to my own interest and the recommendation of @mjbvz at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28380#issuecomment-307544736.

data.title: Ctrl-C doesn't kill process in command prompt when using "open new command prompt" command?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|jshint|dbaeumer|0.10.15|
|vscode-todo-parser|minhthai|1.8.10|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.2|
|language-liquid|neilding|0.0.2|
|vscode-jest|Orta|2.2.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. From Windows, use Ctrl-Shift-C to trigger "Open New Command Prompt" which should launch a cmd.exe window.
2. Run a command and try to kill it with Ctrl-C

Specifically, I'm doing `gulp-watch` which runs a browsersync server. When I open cmd normally and navigate to the same folder, I can run `gulp-watch` and quickly kill it with `Ctrl-C` like I always have. Using "Open New Command Prompt" makes is so the `Ctrl-C` shortcut just copies the selected text (even if there is no selection). I tried this out by making sure I had text in my clipboard and then went back to the window and did a `Ctrl-C` -- when I pasted there was nothing in the clipboard.

Any thoughts?

Thanks!

data.title: Extension host terminated unexpectedly. Please reload the window to recover.
